importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the presidential runoff election in Bolivia, which marked a pivotal political shift ending nearly 20 years of leftist rule.
The inauguration date of Rodrigo Paz as the new President of Bolivia, signaling the beginning of a new political era.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period of nearly two decades of leftist rule under the Movement to Socialism (MAS) party, which ended with the 2025 election.
The timeframe of the current economic crisis and the subsequent political transition, highlighting the urgency of economic reform.

keyTakeAways: Rodrigo Paz, a centrist senator from the Christian Democratic Party (PDC), won Bolivia's presidential runoff election with 54.5% of the vote, defeating conservative candidate Jorge 'Tuto' Quiroga (45.5%).
Paz’s victory marks the end of nearly 20 years of leftist governance under the Movement to Socialism (MAS), which ruled Bolivia continuously since 2006.

Bolivia's worsening economic crisis — including high inflation, plummeting natural gas exports, and fuel shortages — drove widespread voter disillusionment with MAS and fueled a demand for economic change.
Paz’s moderate platform, advocating private sector-led growth and gradual reform, resonated with left-leaning voters who were wary of austerity measures proposed by Quiroga.
Paz’s running mate, Edman Lara, a former police officer with a populist online presence, helped boost his appeal among younger and working-class voters.

Paz’s party, the PDC, won 49 seats in the lower house and 16 in the Senate, just ahead of Quiroga’s coalition, which won 43 and 12 seats respectively, meaning Paz lacks a legislative majority and must form coalitions to govern.
Paz pledged to address fuel shortages through deferred payment agreements with suppliers and to phase out universal fuel subsidies, replacing them with targeted support for vulnerable groups.
The incoming administration faces significant challenges, including securing fuel supplies, navigating fragmented legislature, and avoiding labor union opposition to reforms.

Both candidates pledged to improve diplomatic relations with the United States and sought U.S.-backed financial support to stabilize the economy. Paz unveiled a $1.5 billion economic cooperation deal with U.S. officials.
U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio welcomed the shift, calling the election a 'transformative opportunity' for improved U.S.-Bolivia relations after decades of tension.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Rodrigo Paz, a centrist senator from Bolivia’s Christian Democratic Party (PDC), won the presidential runoff election with 54.5% of the vote, defeating conservative candidate Jorge 'Tuto' Quiroga, marking the end of nearly 20 years of leftist rule under the Movement to Socialism (MAS). The election was driven by Bolivia’s severe economic crisis — including high inflation, declining natural gas exports, and fuel scarcity — which led to widespread voter disillusionment with the MAS government. Paz’s moderate platform, emphasizing private sector growth and gradual reform, appealed to left-leaning voters wary of radical austerity. His running mate, Edman Lara, contributed to his appeal among younger and working-class voters. Despite winning a plurality in the legislature, Paz lacks a majority and must form alliances to govern. He has pledged to address fuel shortages through deferred payments and phase out universal fuel subsidies in favor of targeted support. The incoming administration faces significant challenges, including securing fuel supplies, navigating a fragmented legislature, and avoiding labor union opposition. Both candidates pledged stronger diplomatic relations with the United States, with Paz proposing a $1.5 billion economic cooperation deal. U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio welcomed the shift, calling it a transformative opportunity for improved bilateral relations.
title: Centrist Rodrigo Paz wins Bolivian presidency, ending nearly 20 years of leftist rule
